claim: A number greater than 100 is always a three-digit number

supporting.text: The number 1000 is greater than 100 and has four digits, not three.

attacks.text: The number 1000 is greater than 100 and has four digits, not three.
The claim specifies 'greater than 100' but does not exclude numbers like 101-999, which are three-digit.
The original claim uses 'always', which is absolute and invalidated by any counterexample like 1000.
In mathematical definitions, 'greater than 100' includes all numbers above 100, regardless of digit count.

supporting.text: Any number in the range 1000 to 9999 is greater than 100 and has four digits.

attacks.text: Any number in the range 1000 to 9999 is greater than 100 and has four digits.
The claim specifies 'a number greater than 100' without an upper bound, so numbers like 101-999 are three-digit and support the claim.
The original claim uses 'always,' which is absolute and disproven by the existence of four-digit numbers greater than 100.
In common usage, 'a number greater than 100' might implicitly refer to numbers just above 100 unless context suggests otherwise.

supporting.text: Numbers like 10000 or higher are greater than 100 and have five or more digits.

attacks.text: Numbers like 10000 or higher are greater than 100 and have five or more digits.
The claim specifies 'three-digit number', which excludes numbers with more digits, so A3 is misinterpreting the scope.
The claim is ambiguous—it could mean 'at least three digits' rather than 'exactly three digits', making A3's interpretation plausible.
Mathematical conventions clearly define 'three-digit number' as 100-999, so the claim is false if interpreted literally.

supporting.text: The smallest four-digit number, 1000, is greater than 100 and disproves the claim.

attacks.text: The smallest four-digit number, 1000, is greater than 100 and disproves the claim.
The claim specifies 'a number greater than 100', but 100 itself is not greater than 100, so the claim is about numbers strictly greater than 100.
Even if we consider numbers strictly greater than 100, 101 to 999 are three-digit numbers, but 1000 and above are not.
The original claim uses the word 'always', which is absolute and incorrect since numbers like 1000 exist.

supporting.text: Numbers such as 1001, 2000, or 50000 are all greater than 100 but exceed three digits.

attacks.text: Numbers such as 1001, 2000, or 50000 are all greater than 100 but exceed three digits.
The claim specifies 'a number greater than 100' without any upper limit, so numbers like 1001 are valid counterexamples.
The original claim may have intended to refer to numbers between 100 and 999, which are indeed three-digit numbers.
Even if the claim was intended to refer to numbers between 100 and 999, it is still incorrect as stated because it lacks specificity.
